segment.source: You can pin websites to the Windows 8.1 taskbar for quick access using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013.
segment.target: You can pin websites to the Windows 8.1 taskbar for quick access using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013.

segment.source: Deploy pinned websites using Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)
segment.target: Deploy pinned websites using Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)

segment.source: Deploy pinned websites using Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013
segment.target: Deploy pinned websites using Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 7
segment.target: Windows 7

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)

segment.source: You can pin websites to the Windows 8.1 taskbar for quick access.
segment.target: You can pin websites to the Windows 8.1 taskbar for quick access.

segment.source: You pin a website simply by dragging its tab to the taskbar.
segment.target: You pin a website simply by dragging its tab to the taskbar.

segment.source: Some websites can also extend the icon’s Jump List.
segment.target: Some websites can also extend the icon’s Jump List.

segment.source: The ability to pin websites to the Windows 8.1 taskbar can help make end users in businesses more productive.
segment.target: The ability to pin websites to the Windows 8.1 taskbar can help make end users in businesses more productive.

segment.source: As an IT professional, for example, you can pin intranet and SharePoint websites to the taskbar to make them immediately available to users.
segment.target: As an IT professional, for example, you can pin intranet and SharePoint websites to the taskbar to make them immediately available to users.

segment.source: In this article, you learn how to deploy pinned websites by using Lite Touch Installation in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013.
segment.target: In this article, you learn how to deploy pinned websites by using Lite Touch Installation in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013.

segment.source: Deploying pinned websites in MDT 2013
segment.target: Deploying pinned websites in MDT 2013

segment.source: This topic requires that you have a complete MDT 2013 deployment share that contains Windows 8.1 which comes with Internet Explorer 11.
segment.target: This topic requires that you have a complete MDT 2013 deployment share that contains Windows 8.1 which comes with Internet Explorer 11.

segment.source: If you’re deploying to Windows 7 clients and need to learn how to add IE11 to an MDT 2013 deployment share as an update, see Installing Internet Explorer 11 using Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) in the TechNet library.
segment.target: If you’re deploying to Windows 7 clients and need to learn how to add IE11 to an MDT 2013 deployment share as an update, see Installing Internet Explorer 11 using Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) in the TechNet library.

segment.source: Deploying pinned websites in MDT 2013 is a 4-step process:
segment.target: Deploying pinned websites in MDT 2013 is a 4-step process:

segment.source: Create a .website file for each website that you want to deploy.
segment.target: Create a .website file for each website that you want to deploy.

segment.source: When you pin a website to the taskbar, Windows 8.1 creates a .website file that describes how the icon should look and feel.
segment.target: When you pin a website to the taskbar, Windows 8.1 creates a .website file that describes how the icon should look and feel.

segment.source: Copy the .website files to your deployment share.
segment.target: Copy the .website files to your deployment share.

segment.source: Copy the .website files to your target computers.
segment.target: Copy the .website files to your target computers.

segment.source: Edit the task sequence of your Unattend.xml answer files to pin the websites to the taskbar.
segment.target: Edit the task sequence of your Unattend.xml answer files to pin the websites to the taskbar.

segment.source: In particular, you want to add each .website file to the TaskbarLinks item in Unattend.xml during oobeSystem phase.
segment.target: In particular, you want to add each .website file to the TaskbarLinks item in Unattend.xml during oobeSystem phase.

segment.source: You can add up to six .website files to the TaskbarLinks item.
segment.target: You can add up to six .website files to the TaskbarLinks item.

segment.source: Pinned websites are immediately available to every user who logs on to the computer although the user must click each icon to populate its Jump List.
segment.target: Pinned websites are immediately available to every user who logs on to the computer although the user must click each icon to populate its Jump List.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To follow the examples in this topic, you’ll need to pin the Bing (http://www.bing.com/) and MSN (http://www.msn.com/) websites to the taskbar.
segment.target: To follow the examples in this topic, you’ll need to pin the Bing (http://www.bing.com/) and MSN (http://www.msn.com/) websites to the taskbar.

segment.source: Step 1: Creating .website files
segment.target: Step 1: Creating .website files

segment.source: The first step is to create a .website file for each website that you want to pin to the Windows 8.1 taskbar during deployment.
segment.target: The first step is to create a .website file for each website that you want to pin to the Windows 8.1 taskbar during deployment.

segment.source: A .website file is like a shortcut, except it’s a plain text file that describes not only the website’s URL but also how the icon looks.
segment.target: A .website file is like a shortcut, except it’s a plain text file that describes not only the website’s URL but also how the icon looks.

segment.source: To create each .website file
segment.target: To create each .website file

segment.source: Open the website in IE11.
segment.target: Open the website in IE11.

segment.source: Drag the website’s tab and drop it on the Windows 8.1 taskbar.
segment.target: Drag the website’s tab and drop it on the Windows 8.1 taskbar.

segment.source: Go to in Windows Explorer, and copy the bing.website and msn.website files to your desktop.
segment.target: Go to in Windows Explorer, and copy the bing.website and msn.website files to your desktop.

segment.source: Step 2: Copying the .website files to the deployment share
segment.target: Step 2: Copying the .website files to the deployment share

segment.source: Next, you must enable your deployment share to copy the bing.website and msn.website files to the Start menu on each target computer.
segment.target: Next, you must enable your deployment share to copy the bing.website and msn.website files to the Start menu on each target computer.

segment.source: To copy .website files to the deployment share
segment.target: To copy .website files to the deployment share

segment.source: Open your MDT 2013 deployment share in Windows Explorer.
segment.target: Open your MDT 2013 deployment share in Windows Explorer.

segment.source: In the folder, create the path .
segment.target: In the folder, create the path .

segment.source: If the folder doesn’t exist, create it at the root of your deployment share.
segment.target: If the folder doesn’t exist, create it at the root of your deployment share.

segment.source: Copy the bing.website and msn.website files from your desktop to in your deployment share.
segment.target: Copy the bing.website and msn.website files from your desktop to in your deployment share.

segment.source: Step 3: Copying .website files to target computers
segment.target: Step 3: Copying .website files to target computers

segment.source: After your operating system is installed on the target computer, you need to copy the .website files over so they can be pinned to the taskbar.
segment.target: After your operating system is installed on the target computer, you need to copy the .website files over so they can be pinned to the taskbar.

segment.source: To copy .website files to target computers
segment.target: To copy .website files to target computers

segment.source: In the Deployment Workbench of MDT 2013, open the deployment share containing the task sequence during which you want to deploy pinned websites, and then click Task Sequences.
segment.target: In the Deployment Workbench of MDT 2013, open the deployment share containing the task sequence during which you want to deploy pinned websites, and then click Task Sequences.

segment.source: In the right pane of the Deployment Workbench, right-click your task sequence (create a new one if you don’t have one yet), and click Properties.
segment.target: In the right pane of the Deployment Workbench, right-click your task sequence (create a new one if you don’t have one yet), and click Properties.

segment.source: In the Task Sequence tab, click the Postinstall folder, click General from the Add button, and then click Run Command Line.
segment.target: In the Task Sequence tab, click the Postinstall folder, click General from the Add button, and then click Run Command Line.

segment.source: Rename the newly created item to Copy Files and move it up to the top of the Postinstall folder.
segment.target: Rename the newly created item to Copy Files and move it up to the top of the Postinstall folder.

segment.source: In the Command Line box enter the following text, .
segment.target: In the Command Line box enter the following text, .

segment.source: Click the Apply button to save your changes.
segment.target: Click the Apply button to save your changes.

segment.source: Step 4: Pinning .website files to the Taskbar
segment.target: Step 4: Pinning .website files to the Taskbar

segment.source: With the .website files ready to copy to the Public Links folder on target computers for all users, the last step is to edit the Unattend.xml answer files to pin those .website files to the taskbar.
segment.target: With the .website files ready to copy to the Public Links folder on target computers for all users, the last step is to edit the Unattend.xml answer files to pin those .website files to the taskbar.

segment.source: You will need to complete the following steps for each task sequence during which you want to pin these websites to the taskbar.
segment.target: You will need to complete the following steps for each task sequence during which you want to pin these websites to the taskbar.

segment.source: To pin .website files to the Taskbar
segment.target: To pin .website files to the Taskbar

segment.source: Open the Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: Open the Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: On the OS Info tab, click Edit Unattend.xml to open the Unattend.xml file.
segment.target: On the OS Info tab, click Edit Unattend.xml to open the Unattend.xml file.

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, under Components and then Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup, right-click TaskbarLinks, and then click Add Setting to Pass 7 oobeSystem.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, under Components and then Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup, right-click TaskbarLinks, and then click Add Setting to Pass 7 oobeSystem.

segment.source: In the TaskbarLinks Properties pane, add the relative path to the target computer’s (not the deployment share’s) .website files that you created earlier.
segment.target: In the TaskbarLinks Properties pane, add the relative path to the target computer’s (not the deployment share’s) .website files that you created earlier.

segment.source: You can add up to six links to the TaskbarLinks item.
segment.target: You can add up to six links to the TaskbarLinks item.

segment.source: For example, and
segment.target: For example, and

segment.source: On the File menu, click Save Answer File, and then close Windows SIM.
segment.target: On the File menu, click Save Answer File, and then close Windows SIM.

segment.source: To close the task sequence, click OK.
segment.target: To close the task sequence, click OK.

segment.source: Updating intranet websites for pinning
segment.target: Updating intranet websites for pinning

segment.source: The MDT 2013 deployment share and task sequences are now ready to pin websites to the taskbar during deployment.
segment.target: The MDT 2013 deployment share and task sequences are now ready to pin websites to the taskbar during deployment.

segment.source: This pinning feature can include intranet sites important in your organization.
segment.target: This pinning feature can include intranet sites important in your organization.

segment.source: You can make your intranet websites act more like applications by extending them to fully support the Windows 8.1 taskbar.
segment.target: You can make your intranet websites act more like applications by extending them to fully support the Windows 8.1 taskbar.

segment.source: This includes creating custom Jump Lists, thumbnail previews, and notifications.
segment.target: This includes creating custom Jump Lists, thumbnail previews, and notifications.

segment.source: For info about extending your intranet websites, see Pinned Sites Developer Documentation on MSDN.
segment.target: For info about extending your intranet websites, see Pinned Sites Developer Documentation on MSDN.

segment.source: For more ideas about what to pin, see Add-ons in the Internet Explorer Gallery.
segment.target: For more ideas about what to pin, see Add-ons in the Internet Explorer Gallery.
